```{r}
library(quantmod)  # Get stock data
library(tidyverse) # Data manipulation & plotting
library(gganimate) # Animation
library(gifski)    # GIF rendering


```

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false
#| results: 'hide'

tickers <- c("AAPL", "MSFT", "AMZN", "GOOGL", "NVDA", "META", "TSLA")
getSymbols(tickers, src = "yahoo", from = "2018-01-01", to = Sys.Date())

# Combine and clean data
prices <- map(tickers, ~Ad(get(.x))) %>% 
  reduce(merge) %>% 
  `colnames<-`(tickers) %>% 
  fortify.zoo(name = "Date") %>% 
  pivot_longer(-Date, names_to = "Stock", values_to = "Price")

```

```{r}
events <- tibble(
  Date = as.Date(c("2018-03-22", "2018-07-06", "2018-09-24",
                  "2019-05-10", "2019-09-01", "2025-06-15")),
  Label = c("$50B Tariff", "First Tariff", "$200B Tariffs",
           "25% Increase", "Consumer Tariffs", "New Tariff"),
  y_end = c(800, 850, 900, 950, 1000, 1050) # Line stopping points
)

```

This project analyzes the impact of U.S. tariffs on the "Magnificent Seven" technology stocksâ€”Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet, Meta, Nvidia, and Teslaâ€”using historical stock price data sourced from Yahoo Finance via the quantmod package in R. The code processes adjusted closing prices from 2018 through mid-2025, visualizing price movements alongside key tariff event dates. These tariffs, announced and implemented at various points between 2018 and 2025, have significantly influenced market valuations, causing sharp declines and volatility in these tech giantsâ€™ stocks. For example, following tariff announcements, the Magnificent Seven collectively lost trillions in market value, with intermittent rebounds when tariffs were paused or eased. By integrating tariff event labels directly into animated stock price charts with gganimate, the project clearly illustrates how trade policy uncertainty and tariff actions have shaped investor sentiment and stock performance over time.
